author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: For ‘The Late Americans,’ Grad School Life Equals Envy, Sex and Ennui
description: Brandon Taylor’s novel circulates among Iowa City residents, some privileged, some not, but all aware that their possibilities are contracting.
content: Reading Brandon Taylor’s new novel, “The Late Americans,” I thought more than once of the Bad Sex in Fiction Award that the English magazine Literary Review gave to decades of authors, many esteemed, before showing mercy in pandemic-chilled 2020. Not because the sex in Taylor’s novel is described badly, but because — described well! — so much of it is bad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Tankersley and Catie Edmondson
title: Biden and McCarthy Set to Resume Negotiations on Debt Limit
description: Discussions aimed at avoiding a default have bogged down as Republicans press their demand for spending caps, work requirements for public benefit programs and other proposals in exchange.
content: President Biden and Speaker Kevin McCarthy agreed on Sunday to meet on Monday afternoon to try to jump-start talks aimed at averting a default on the nation’s debt, capping a tumultuous stretch of negotiations that faltered over the weekend as the two sides clashed over Republicans’ demands to cut spending in exchange for raising the debt limit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Onstage in ‘An American Tail,’ a Family’s Jewishness Comes to the Fore
description: The Children’s Theater Company production, based on the animated film, elevates the depiction of its characters’ religious and ethnic backgrounds.
content: The 1986 animated feature film “An American Tail” begins with a mouse family, the Mousekewitzes, forced to flee their home after men on horseback (and accompanying cats) set fire to their village in Russia in 1885. They travel to the United States, because, Papa sings, “there are no cats in America, and the streets are paved with cheese!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing: The G7 Wraps
description: Also, Russia claims that it captured Bakhmut.
content: The G7 summit concluded yesterday in Japan with leaders of the world’s major economies welcoming President Volodymyr Zelensky as an honored guest and reaffirming their support of Ukraine. But Russia claimed victory in Bakhmut, even though Ukraine says that it still holds a few blocks of the ruined city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: Koepka Wins P.G.A. Championship, Vanquishing Demons and Boosting LIV
description: Koepka claimed his fifth major championship when he outlasted a swarm of stars on Sunday at Oak Hill Country Club near Rochester, N.Y.
content: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — Six weeks ago on Sunday, Brooks Koepka did not sleep. He had brooding to do and demons to chase. After everything — the ghastly knee injury, the agony of unfulfilled ambition, the taunts and the splenetic rift in professional golf that he helped personify — he had rallied to a Masters Tournament lead, and then he had fizzled. Collapsed, really.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: Ukraine May Be Finally Getting the F-16s It Asked For. Why Did It Want Them?
description: Ukraine’s sizable contingent of fighter jets come with a few problems. President Volodymyr Zelensky said F-16s would “greatly enhance our army in the sky.”
content: Since Russia’s full-scale invasion of Ukraine began over a year ago, officials in Kyiv have been asking their Western allies to supply the country’s air force with advanced warplanes such as the F-16. But the United States, which manufactures the fighter jet, was long reluctant to provide it, or to allow other countries that have F-16s to re-export them to Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Weinman
title: A Classic of Golden Age Detective Fiction Turns 100
description: Dorothy L. Sayers dealt with emotional and financial instability by writing “Whose Body?,” the first of many to star the detective Lord Peter Wimsey.
content: In a 1937 essay, the English writer Dorothy L. Sayers explained the genesis of her most famous character and one of crime fiction’s most memorable detectives, Lord Peter Wimsey. “When in a lighthearted manner I set out, 15 years ago, to write the first ‘Lord Peter’ book,” she wrote, “it was with the avowed intention of producing something ‘less like a conventional detective story and more like a novel.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: The Club That Wants Nothing to Do With Russia
description: In the 1990s, the G7 invited Russia to join, a sign of its ascendence. Today, Vladimir V. Putin is on the outside, as his enemy, Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, is the honored guest.
content: What a difference a quarter-century makes. When I covered my first Group of 7 meeting in 1997 in Denver, it was the beginning of a new era. President Bill Clinton, the host, invited President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia to participate and rebranded the meeting “the Summit of the Eight.” From that point on, Russia was part of the club, and the G7 soon became the G8.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: At a Soaked P.G.A. Championship, Backward Ball Caps and the Umbrella Dance
description: Driving rain on Saturday at the P.G.A. Championship forced some golfers to buck the usual country club sartorial norms in order to keep the water out of their eyes.
content: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — For a while during the third round of the P.G.A. Championship on Saturday, Rory McIlroy, Justin Thomas, Scottie Scheffler, Justin Rose, Adam Scott and three or four other golfers were roaming the august grounds of the Oak Hill Country Club with their caps on backward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hurubie Meko
title: Daniel Penny Gives First Interview Addressing Subway Killing
description: Mr. Penny, who has been charged in the killing of Jordan Neely on May 1, gave few details about the confrontation in an interview with The New York Post.
content: Nearly three weeks after he was captured on video choking Jordan Neely, a homeless man, to death on a New York City subway, Daniel Penny spoke publicly about the episode for the first time on Saturday in an interview with The New York Post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: The Secret to Better Salmon Is Salt
description: A dry brine gives you firmer, juicier fish fillets with kettle-chip-crisp skin.
content: Good morning. J. Kenji López-Alt went full Kenji recently and dove deep into the process of dry-brining salmon to achieve firmer, juicier, less albumin-stained cooked fillets. I admire the tenacity of Kenji’s reporting, and I’m absolutely thrilled to report that while he calls for an overnight cure on the fish, I’ve achieved excellent results in just an afternoon’s time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Minnesota Passes Bill Seeking to Ensure Minimum Wage for Gig Workers
description: Lyft and Uber have opposed the legislation, threatening to reduce operations or leave the state if it is enacted.
content: The Minnesota Senate passed a bill on Sunday that would guarantee drivers for Uber and Lyft a minimum wage and other benefits, sending the measure to Gov. Tim Walz.
source.name: The New York Times

title: When Corporations Take Over Health Care
description: Readers lament a growing trend in American health care. Also: The new philanthropists; children of older mothers.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina and Claire Fahy
title: Typhoon Mawar Expected to Hit Guam by Wednesday
description: Forecasters said the storm is strengthening as it approaches the Mariana Islands, with sustained winds of 80 miles per hour.
content: What was Tropical Storm Mawar has strengthened in the Pacific into a typhoon and was expected to make landfall on Wednesday, bringing high winds and possible flooding to the Mariana Islands, including Guam, the National Weather Service said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: How ‘Decoupling’ From China Became ‘De-risking’
description: The newly fashionable term, reflecting an evolution in the discussion over dealing with a rising, assertive China, has a vexing history in financial policy.
content: If diplomats were on TikTok, “de-risk” would be trending. The word has suddenly become popular among officials trying to loosen China’s grip on global supply chains but not cut ties entirely, with the joint communiqué from this weekend’s Group of 7 meeting making clear that the world’s largest democratic economies will now focus on “de-risking, not decoupling.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: DeSantis Skirts Abortion Ban Even When Speaking to His Base
description: The Florida governor is reluctant to talk about the restrictive law he signed as he seeks to attract support from across the Republican Party.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida could not have asked for a friendlier venue to highlight the sweeping six-week abortion ban he signed last month: an annual gala hosted by a deeply conservative Christian group that welcomed him with a sustained standing ovation and provided a bagpiper in full Highland regalia playing “Amazing Grace.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Lipton
title: Start-Ups Bring Silicon Valley Ethos to a Lumbering Military-Industrial Complex
description: Small, fast-moving U.S. tech firms are using the war in Ukraine to demonstrate a new generation of military systems but face the challenge of selling them to a risk-averse Defense Department.
content: Capella Space, a San Francisco-based start-up, is building a fleet of small, inexpensive satellites that can track enemy troops as they move at night, or under cloud cover that traditional optical satellites cannot see through.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Why Ukraine Needs Those F-16s
description: The need for control of the nation’s airspace is one of the war’s largely untold stories.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — On Friday morning, local time, I received news of one of the best American decisions of the war: The White House would no longer block its European allies from supplying Ukraine with American-made F-16 fighters, a move that should greatly enhance Ukrainian military capabilities without significantly increasing the risk of unacceptable escalation in its conflict with Russia. (The decision still needs to be approved by some congressional leaders.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Dominus
title: A Reporter Who Puts Herself Into Perspective
description: Susan Dominus uses first-person narration to humanize her reporting — even when she’s writing about topics such as therapy or menopause.
content: When I speak to journalism students, I usually advise them to use the first person point of view in their reported works with caution. Writing in the first person can make for facile transitions (“I met her at a crowded restaurant”) or reveal reporters’ mistaken impressions of their own significance to a story. It can set up the expectation of more personal insights to come that are never realized; often, it simply feels extraneous or clumsy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: What Russia’s Claim to Capture Bakhmut Means for the Ukraine War
description: Capturing Bakhmut would be Russia’s most significant territorial gain in Ukraine since last summer, but its ability to hold the city or advance further is in question.
content: Russia’s claim of victory in Bakhmut suggests that the brutal urban combat that marked the deadliest battle of its war in Ukraine might be over. But what comes next is far from clear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: ‘Living in Fear’: Arson Is the Latest in a String of Attacks on Minnesota Mosques
description: A fire last week at a mosque in St. Paul, Minn., was at least the fifth such act of vandalism against Muslim houses of worship in the state so far this year, officials said. The suspect in the latest fire said he was Muslim and was protesting homelessness.
content: A suspect was arrested on suspicion of arson after a fire last week at a mosque in St. Paul, Minn., at least the fifth such act of vandalism in the state so far this year that has left members of the Muslim community “living in fear,” a state senator said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marisa Meltzer
title: Where the Bees Are Famous (and the Goats Wear Cashmere)
description: Welcome to Flamingo Estate.
content: LOS ANGELES — Flamingo Estate, a lifestyle company set in a 1940s Spanish-style house in the hills on the border between the Eagle Rock and Highland Park neighborhoods, sells candles that smell like tomatoes and rosemary. Oprah Winfrey named them one of her favorite things.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Bozzone
title: How a Food Stylist and Housewares Designer Spends Her Sundays
description: Mariana Velásquez likes to take long strolls through her new neighborhood and have friends over for a casual one-pot meal.
content: In 2020, Mariana Velásquez had planned to go on a 12-day road trip through Colombia to photograph her new cookbook, “Colombiana.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Diamond
title: A History of ‘Record’ in the Newspaper of Record
description: The word saw, ahem, record usage in The New York Times in 2008.
content: On Dec. 1, 1937, the bottom right corner of Page 41 of The New York Times featured a brief, self-referential advertisement:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Horowitz
title: As Greece Votes, Leader Says Blocking Migrants Built ‘Good Will’ With Europe
description: Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis has taken a tough line on migrants as he turns around the country’s economy. It’s a trade-off that voters and the European Union seem more than willing to abide.
content: Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis of Greece has been accused of illegally pushing asylum seekers back at sea. He has acknowledged that the state’s intelligence service wiretapped an opposition leader. He has consolidated media control as press freedom in Greece has dropped to the lowest in Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Uber’s Diversity Chief Put on Leave After Complaints of Insensitivity
description: The executive hosted sessions about race and being a white woman that were titled “Don’t Call Me Karen,” prompting an employee uproar.
content: Uber has placed its longtime head of diversity, equity and inclusion on leave after workers complained that an employee event she moderated, titled “Don’t Call Me Karen,” was insensitive to people of color.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: The U.S. Needs Minerals for Electric Cars. Everyone Else Wants Them Too.
description: The United States is entering an array of agreements to secure the critical minerals necessary for the energy transition, but it’s not clear which of the arrangements can succeed.
content: For decades, a group of the world’s biggest oil producers has held huge sway over the American economy and the popularity of U.S. presidents through its control of the global oil supply, with decisions by the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries determining what U.S. consumers pay at the pump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esther Zuckerman
title: Living With the Men of Paul Schrader’s ‘Man in a Room’ Trilogy
description: Joel Edgerton, Oscar Isaac and Ethan Hawke explain how they worked with the writer-director, known for solitary characters grappling with sin and redemption.
content: The writer-director Paul Schrader has a metaphor he likes to use with his leading men.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: May 21, 2023
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, May 21, 2023.
content: An article on Page 14 this weekend about the rapper Killer Mike misspells the name of Killer Mike’s wife. She is Shana Render, not Shayna.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sandomir
title: Helmut Berger, Actor Known for His Work With Visconti, Dies at 78
description: He first made his mark in “The Damned” as a character one critic said personified “the outright perversion” of Nazism. He went on to have a long career, mostly in Europe.
content: Helmut Berger, a handsome Austrian movie star who was best known for appearing in three feature films by the Italian neorealist director Luchino Visconti, his lover for a dozen years, died on Thursday at his home in Salzburg. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By German Lopez
title: The Evidence for Therapy
description: Does talk therapy work? It’s complicated.
content: Millions of Americans go to talk therapy. But does it work? It’s a surprisingly difficult question to answer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Sudan’s Warring Groups Agree to 7-Day Cease-Fire
description: The truce is the first to be signed by both sides. It followed weeks of talks in Saudi Arabia between representatives of the two rival generals vying for power in the northeast African nation.
content: Sudan’s warring parties have agreed to a seven-day cease-fire beginning on Monday, Saudi Arabia and the United States announced late Saturday, the first truce to be signed by both parties in a conflict that has raged for over a month, leaving millions of people across the northeast African nation in a dire humanitarian crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: As Rahm Emanuel Pushes Japan on Gay Rights, Conservatives Bristle
description: The U.S. ambassador has enthusiastically embraced his host country. But critics say he has overstepped diplomatic bounds with his advocacy on equality.
content: Since taking up his post as U.S. ambassador to Japan last year, Rahm Emanuel has lavished his host country with enthusiastic tweets about riding the world-class bullet trains and subways, hiking Mount Fuji or sampling local delicacies and festivals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer
title: As Russia Claims Victory in Bakhmut, Ukraine Sees Opportunity Amid Ruins
description: Military analysts say that if Moscow continues to send reinforcements to defend the city, that could weaken Russian forces’ ability to hold off a broader counteroffensive that Ukraine has been planning.
content: Russia’s claim of victory in the eastern Ukrainian city of Bakhmut suggests that the brutal urban combat that marked the deadliest battle of its war in Ukraine might be over. But what comes next is far from clear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch and Joshua Needelman
title: 30 Tons of Explosive Chemicals Lost During Rail Shipment
description: The chemical, ammonium nitrate, is relatively harmless by itself but has caused deadly explosions in industrial accidents and has been used in targeted attacks.
content: About 60,000 pounds of ammonium nitrate, a chemical used as a fertilizer and in explosives, went missing on a rail shipment from Wyoming to California in April and has still not been found, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: What Bills Did DeSantis Sign as He Propelled Florida to the Right?
description: Gov. Ron DeSantis ushered in a six-week abortion ban and curriculum restrictions, while expanding capital punishment and concealed carry access as he prepared to run for president.
content: Seeking to elevate his stock with his Republican base for his presumptive presidential candidacy, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida this year has checked off many boxes on a far-right wish list of laws restricting abortion rights, gender-transition care for minors and teaching about sexual orientation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder and Desiree Rios
title: Brooks Koepka Surges to the Lead at P.G.A. Championship
description: After his second consecutive four-under-par 66, the LIV golfer Koepka will be in the final pairing on Sunday at Oak Hill Country Club.
content: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — Four years ago, less than a week before he won his second consecutive P.G.A. Championship, Brooks Koepka allowed the world inside his swaggering mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marie Solis
title: The Week in Business: An Attempt to Ban TikTok
description: The latest clash between Florida’s governor and Disney. The looming X-date. And the boom this year in corporate bankruptcies.
content: The backlash against TikTok, the video app that has come under scrutiny largely because of its Chinese ownership, reached a new level on Wednesday, when Gov. Greg Gianforte of Montana signed a bill banning the app in the state. The legislation seeks to cut off access by targeting mobile app stores, like the Apple Store and Google Play, and prohibit them from offering TikTok in Montana. If the stores continue allowing people to download the app, the companies could face fines, as could TikTok. The ban is set to take effect on Jan. 1, but it is already facing a legal challenge. On Thursday, a group of TikTok users filed a lawsuit contending that the law violated their First Amendment rights and that the ban outstripped Montana’s legal authority as a state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang Che
title: China Bans Some Sales of Chips From U.S. Company Micron
description: Many analysts see the move as retaliation for Washington’s efforts to cut off China’s access to high-end chips.
content: Beijing on Sunday told Chinese companies that deal with critical information to stop purchasing products from Micron Technology, the U.S.-based manufacturer of memory chips used in phones, computers and other electronics. Many analysts viewed the move as retaliation for Washington’s efforts to cut off China’s access to high-end chips.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘The Crowd of People Waiting for Their Orders Was Packed to the Walls’
description: A busy bagel shop, a call gets a surprising response and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | May 22, 2023
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: Note: This is our last “What’s Going On in This Picture?” for the 2022-23 school year. The feature will resume in September.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: A Baffert Horse Wins on the Same Day That Another Is Fatally Injured
description: Returning to the Triple Crown trail after a suspension, Bob Baffert watched his colt National Treasure win the Preakness after another one of his horses died during an undercard race.
content: Bob Baffert, the most accomplished and controversial horse trainer in America, returned to the Triple Crown trail on Saturday and watched his colt National Treasure win the 148th running of the Preakness Stakes. The victory came after Baffert’s two-year ban from the sport’s premier stage because of a doping violation, and hours after another one of his horses died competing in an undercard race at Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenna Russell
title: As Boston’s New Mayor Seeks Big Changes, Old Power Brokers Push Back
description: Mayor Michelle Wu is striving to keep her campaign promises, but powerful lobbies are throwing up roadblocks.
content: When Mayor Michelle Wu cracked down on outdoor dining in Boston’s congested North End neighborhood last year, appeasing residents beleaguered by crowds, trash and blocked sidewalks, restaurant owners made their displeasure known, protesting at City Hall and filing a lawsuit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Roberts
title: What Number Comes Next? The Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences Knows.
description: The “mathematical equivalent to the FBI’s voluminous fingerprint files” turns 50 this year, with 362,765 entries (and counting).
content: Some numbers are odd:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Susan Stubson
title: What Christian Nationalism Has Done to My State and My Faith Is a Sin
description: Wyoming’s new crop of lawmakers seems intent on stripping us of our autonomy and our ability to make decisions for ourselves.
content: CASPER, Wyo. — I first saw it while working the rope line at a monster-truck rally during the 2016 campaign by my husband, Tim, for Wyoming’s lone congressional seat. As Tim and I and our boys made our way down the line, shaking hands and passing out campaign material, a burly man wearing a “God bless America” T-shirt and a cross around his neck said something like, “He’s got my vote if he keeps those [epithet] out of office,” using a racial slur. What followed was an uncomfortable master class in racism and xenophobia as the man decanted the reasons our country is going down the tubes. God bless America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Haney and Lomachenko Give Lightweight Boxing Another Close Bout
description: Devin Haney won, but plenty of people thought Vasiliy Lomachenko should have. The tight matchup opens up options in boxing’s deep lightweight division.
content: By the time Devin Haney strolled into the post-fight news conference at the MGM Grand Garden Arena in Las Vegas, the 24-year-old undisputed lightweight champion was aware of the widespread perception that judges had erred in awarding him a unanimous decision win over Vasiliy Lomachenko on Saturday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King
title: What Tim Scott’s 2024 Campaign Could Mean for Black Republicans
description: The South Carolina senator’s bid for the White House — as the sole Black Republican in the Senate — could raise not only his profile, but those of Black conservatives across the country.
content: Senator Tim Scott, Republican of South Carolina, addressed the Charleston County Republican Party at a dinner in February, offering a stirring message of unity and American redemption that has become the center of his stump speech. The next day, he called the chairman of the county party to ask for his support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Gloria Molina, Pioneering Latina Politician, Dies at 74
description: In three elections, she was a “first,” becoming one of the leading Latina politicians in California and the country.
content: Gloria Molina, a groundbreaking Chicana politician at the city, county and state levels in California who was a fierce advocate for the communities she represented, even though that often meant defying entrenched political structures, died on May 14 at her home in the Mount Washington neighborhood of Los Angeles. She was 74.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oussama Zahr
title: Review: Pulling Back the Curtain on ‘The Magic Flute’ at the Met
description: Unveiling the trickery only enhances the delight of this interpretation of Mozart by the director Simon McBurney.
content: The lights were still on in the auditorium — and audience members were still milling about in the aisles — when the orchestra struck up the overture to Mozart’s “Die Zauberflöte” at the Metropolitan Opera House on Friday evening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: With His Party Ahead in Elections, Greek Leader Claims ‘Political Earthquake’
description: Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis’s New Democracy party did not win enough votes to form a one-party government. But he appeared to rule out talks to form a coalition, setting the stage for a second vote in weeks.
content: The party of Greece’s conservative prime minister, Kyriakos Mitsotakis, was on track to win a decisive victory in the general election on Sunday but fell short of the majority required to lead a one-party government, setting the stage for another ballot within weeks since Mr. Mitsotakis appeared to rule out forming a governing coalition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: Russia’s Latest Sanctions on U.S. Officials Turn to Trump Enemies
description: Among the 500 people singled out for travel and financial restrictions were Americans seen as adversaries by former President Donald J. Trump.
content: Russia has expanded its list of sanctioned Americans in a tit-for-tat retaliation for the latest curbs imposed by the United States. But what is particularly striking is how much President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is adopting perceived enemies of former President Donald J. Trump as his own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington and Desiree Rios
title: Michael Block’s Incredible P.G.A. Championship Adventure
description: Block, a club pro from Arroyo Trabuco, shot par in each of the first three rounds and on Sunday was paired with Rory McIlroy. He thought it couldn’t get better. Then he got a hole in one.
content: PITTSFORD, N.Y. — On Saturday evening, Michael Block, the 46-year-old Everyman golf pro from a public course in California, learned that he would continue his enchanting run at this year’s P.G.A. Championship by playing the final round with Rory McIlroy, the four-time major champion. Block rolled his eyes at the news and spun around.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: 12 Dead in Soccer Stadium Stampede in El Salvador
description: It was not immediately clear what prompted the rush at Cuscatlán Stadium in the capital. President Nayib Bukele vowed to conduct a thorough investigation.
content: Twelve people died and about 90 others were injured in a stampede at a soccer stadium in El Salvador on Saturday, the authorities said, turning a highly anticipated match into a chaotic scene as fans rushed to save people suffocating under a mass of bodies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: Images of a Ruined Hiroshima Remind Zelensky of Present-Day Bakhmut
description: While it “wouldn’t be fair” to compare Hiroshima to what is happening in his country, Ukraine’s president said the city’s atomic bomb museum offered grim echoes of fresh devastation.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine wrapped up his appearance at the Group of 7 summit in Japan with a visit to Hiroshima’s atomic bomb museum, saying on Sunday that he saw echoes of his own country’s pain in images of the 1945 devastation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: N.A.A.C.P. Issues Florida Travel Advisory, Joining Latino and L.G.B.T.Q. Groups
description: The N.A.A.C.P. urged people to consider Florida’s policies on diversity and race under Gov. Ron DeSantis when thinking of traveling there.
content: The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People on Saturday issued a travel advisory for Florida, saying that under Gov. Ron DeSantis the state has become “openly hostile toward African Americans, people of color and L.G.B.T.Q.+ individuals.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz and Federico Rios
title: The U.S. Left Them Behind. They Crossed a Jungle to Get Here Anyway.
description: For thousands of Afghans, the American withdrawal from Kabul was just the beginning of a long, dangerous search for safety.
content: Taiba was being hunted by the men she had put behind bars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Language Family
description: Dang Quang Thang names names in his puzzle debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues | Solving Tip
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington and Desiree Rios
title: Putting the ‘Oak’ — More Than 40,000 of Them — in Oak Hill
description: Over 40 years, Dr. John R. Williams nurtured thousands of acorns, including some from Sherwood Forest and George Washington’s estate, into towering oak trees. His obsession had a singular goal — transform the grounds of this year’s P.G.A. Championship.
content: Rob Galbraith remembers, as a child in the early 1960s, regularly going to the Rochester, N.Y., home of his great-grandfather, John R. Williams who had been a pioneering physician in the area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker, Motoko Rich and David E. Sanger
title: Biden Announces More Aid for Ukraine as Group of 7 Powers Meet in Japan
description: President Volodomyr Zelensky of Ukraine received vows of resolute support and promises of further weapons shipments even as Russian forces claimed to have seized the war-torn city of Bakhmut.
content: HIROSHIMA, Japan — President Biden and other leaders of the world’s major industrial democracies rallied around Ukraine on Sunday with vows of resolute support and promises of further weapons shipments even as Russian forces claimed to have seized full control of a bitterly contested city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma Grillo and Max Berlinger
title: Ali Wong at a Fancy House Party, and a Stylish Gala at PS1
description: Jeremy O. Harris celebrated art stars, while Dwyane Wade and Gabrielle Union showed up for Loewe.
content: Los Angeles is so consumed with celebrity that even some houses are famous. Take the Sheats-Goldstein residence, a co-star in films like “The Big Lebowski.” Last Friday the e-commerce site Mytheresa leveraged its renown to fete the new Paula’s Ibiza collection from Loewe, a beachy capsule the brand has released each summer since 2017. “This is the playful part of the brand,” said Tiffany Hsu, Mytheresa’s vice president for buying.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: Liberals Are Persuading Themselves of a Debt Ceiling Plan That Won’t Work
description: The limit Congress imposes is dumb, but Biden can’t just wave it away.
content: The debt ceiling might be the single dumbest feature of American law. Congress decides to spend money and later schedules a separate vote on whether the government will pay its bills. If the government doesn’t pay its bills, calamity ensues.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang
title: Inside the Barbecue City That Is China’s Hottest Tourist Destination
description: Zibo has become a social media star for its distinctive barbecue style. Now the city is overrun with visitors.
content: The flame-shaped neon archway was visible from miles away, which was good since there was little other reason for anyone to be in that part of town, an expanse of fields outside an industrial city in eastern China. The lights flickered between icy blue and red-hot, leaping toward the night sky beside a jumbo sign: “Zibo Barbecue Experiential Ground.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: We Should Be More ‘Amish’ About Technology
description: Living fully online can put the higher goods in our lives at risk.
content: The first time I truly admitted that something was awry with my use of social media was the day of my daughter’s first-grade Christmas performance in 2019. She’d been anticipating the show for weeks, practicing her song again and again. I’d rearranged my work schedule to be there and was running a little late but could make it in time if I hurried. As I was getting ready to leave, a Twitter conversation was on my mind — a mind that was locked into Twitter often enough that it thought in 280-character bites, composed unbidden tweets constantly and always felt a little twitchy and restless.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gordon Witkin
title: Here’s What We Can Do Now About Gun Violence
description: Fixing the background check system can be done today, but it will take work.
content: A litany of exasperating rituals flows from America’s regular mass shootings. One of the most frustrating is the hand-wringing that our politics is so polarized that there’s no way to move forward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: On the Denver Nuggets, the Role Players Get to Be Stars, Too
description: The Nuggets can sweep the Lakers in the Western Conference finals, and it’s not just because of Nikola Jokic and Jamal Murray. The role players have been just as important.
content: LOS ANGELES — To win a championship in the N.B.A., a team almost always needs at least one transcendent player.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Desert Provides a New Paradise for Hawaiians
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, May 21, 2023.
content: “We got priced out of paradise. But all these traditions, all our language, it’s part of our identity.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniela J. Lamas
title: Not Every Pandemic Needs Someone to Blame
description: A case for ending the epidemic blame game.
content: Three years ago, as I stood at the bedside of my first patient with the coronavirus, I struggled to understand why someone relatively young and healthy had become so sick. The unknown of the virus was frightening enough — to think that severe illness could strike at random was untenable. Even in my personal protective equipment, I held my breath, suddenly aware of my own vulnerability. The air itself felt dangerous.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Njideka Akunyili Crosby Wants to Take it Slow, Despite Her Rapid Rise
description: The Nigerian artist inaugurates Zwirner’s new Los Angeles gallery with paintings that showcase her artistic vernacular.
content: LOS ANGELES — To listen to Njideka Akunyili Crosby talk about the lengths to which she’ll go in researching the scientific classification of plants to depict in one of her paintings — Madagascar Jasmine? Safari Sunset? — is to begin to understand this Nigerian artist’s slow and exacting approach, as well as why her new exhibition, inaugurating David Zwirner’s first Los Angeles gallery on May 23, feels like a significant art world event.
source.name: The New York Times
